awd_titl_txt: The Research Advancement among Careers and Education for Success in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (RACE for Success in STEM)
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSI  Program), this Track 1 project aims to diminish weaknesses in solving problems and critical thinking skills in mathematics, English, and Spanish among first-year science students. The Research Advancement among Careers and Education for Success in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (RACE for Success in STEM) at Pontifical Catholic University of Puerto Rico-Ponce Campus (PCUPR) is a two-year interdisciplinary research project with a holistic approach. The project also aims to integrate social issues, which are vital elements of their emotional stability, self-confidence, and self-motivation at the undergraduate level. Students who will participate in our project are affected by today's socioeconomic hardships, academic adversity, and natural events like Hurricane Maria, Earthquakes, and COVID-19. Therefore, this project plans to compensate with a complete set of components that address the academic disparities and interpersonal intelligence. This project design will enhance the educational capacity, research skills, and sense of belonging of first-year undergraduate Hispanic students to improve retention and graduation rates in STEM fields.

The RACE for Success in STEM specific aims are: (1) To improve students' foundational academic skills needed to excel in STEM education; (2) To develop new strategies that support student transitions to advanced STEM careers through the information obtained from the student's family and social context; (3) To promote retention and inclusion by providing research, critical thinking and reading comprehension activities, empowering the students with skills necessary for the future; and (4) To elicit a sense of belonging in STEM education through peer-leading and research-leading activities. This proposal is a pilot project that will use a mixed-method design with qualitative (interviews and focal groups) and quantitative (GPA, course grades, and surveys) data. The proposed project consists of a pilot group compared to the rest of the student group (control) of freshman students registered in mathematics, English, and Spanish.  The pilot group will also participate in the Student Developmental Plan consisting of the Self-Management Skills Development Program and the First Experience Summer Research Internship. The expected outcomes will show improvements in retention, academic performance, and persistence among first-year students and within the workforce in STEM.  The proposed project will impact the curriculum in courses like Math, Spanish, and English, leaving an Institutional legacy with a new program in peer-leading and research-leading activities well designed and essential for students' success in STEM. The researchers will disseminate the project outcomes to the community through brief reports and local and national meetings (e.g., HSI Program). This study's activities and results will also be available online to the interested public through our home page: http://pucpr.edu, a section dedicated to the Pilot Project: RACE for Success in STEM. The HSI Program aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education, broaden participation in STEM, and build capacity at HSIs. Achieving these aims, given the diverse nature and context of the HSIs, requires innovative approaches that incentivize institutional and community transformation and promote fundamental research (i) on engaged student learning, (ii) about what it takes to diversify and increase participation in STEM effectively, and (iii) that improves our understanding of how to build institutional capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI Program will also draw from these approaches to generate new knowledge on how to achieve these aims.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Research Advancement among Careers and Education for Success in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (RACE for Success in STEM) is a unique research project at PCUPR. It stands out due to its holistic approach, which emphasizes that every aspect of a student's academic life contributes to their success.  The project addresses systemic barriers faced by underrepresented students through a multidisciplinary approach, impacting different academic fields like Spanish, English, and Mathematics, which are essential for student comprehension and success in STEM. Moreover, the project integrates Puerto Rican students' social issues and family matters as critical factors in the decision-making to enter and persevere in a STEM career pathway. These elements are vital for a student’s emotional stability, self-confidence, and self-motivation at the undergraduate level.

This project advances knowledge on the efficacy of student support strategies—such as  interactive tutoring  (a personalized approach to teaching that involves one-on-one interaction between the tutor and the student in Spanish, English, Mathematics);  Math Bootcamp (a math review before university entry); Peer-leading integration (a peer-to-peer learning model that fosters collaboration and knowledge sharing); and research participation—that positively impacted the retention attrition index of STEM students. Additionally, the project incorporates psychoeducational activities that help students manage their first-year experiences effectively. It also conducted a family context study to explore how parents perceive STEM education as a career and how natural events influence these views.

This project effectively met the needs of minority students at a Hispanic-Serving Institution: (a) by successfully addressing the need to improve students' foundational academic skills, a crucial prerequisite for excelling in STEM education, (b) by providing targeted support and resources that empowered students to enhance their academic skills, laying a solid foundation for their future studies and careers in STEM,  (c) by developing new strategies that support student transitions to advanced STEM careers, incorporating insights obtained from the student's family and social contexts to create a holistic and culturally responsive approach.

Furthermore, the project is dedicated to promoting retention and inclusion by providing research, critical thinking, and reading comprehension activities. These activities are designed to empower students with the skills necessary for their future in STEM education. By focusing on these key competencies, the project aims to instill a sense of confidence and capability in the students, preparing them to navigate the challenges and opportunities that lie ahead. Additionally, the project cultivates a strong sense of belonging in STEM education through peer-leading and research-driven activities, encouraging collaboration and leadership while reinforcing students' connection to the STEM community.

This pilot project developed online modules for Spanish, English, and Mathematics to address educational gaps that pose significant barriers to first-year students' engagement in STEM. These modules have improved the university's infrastructure and students' technological and informational literacy. This program has provided students with their first research experience through a summer research internship for first-year students at PCUPR. Furthermore, tutors, mentors and participants have received leadership training, directly and indirectly, which has enhanced their sense of belonging and well-being. The families of PCUPR STEM students have also been involved in this project to explore their careers in science and technology. Through the activities outlined above, the participants have acquired the knowledge and skills necessary to overcome their weaknesses through targeted interventions, experiencing increased confidence in navigating STEM disciplines.

As a result of RACE activities, the participants (n=16) improved their GPAs (0.3-0.5, above PCUPR students average) in Mathematics, Spanish, and English.  RACE participants during the project period 2022-24 increased their passing grades in mathematic MATH 141 in comparison to their classmates, 95% vs 74.88%.  Likewise, on MATH 142, RACE participants obtained 100% passing grades with C or above, while only 74.48% of the PCUPR students approved the course.

In addition, the retention rate among RACE participants (attrition of 1:16) exceeded the overall PCUPR student retention rate (attrition of 1:12), underscoring the program's effectiveness in fostering persistence in STEM in the College of Science. The 'crew effect', a term we use to describe the powerful influence of peer support significantly enhanced participants’ integration into university life and supported their persistence in STEM despite major external challenges, such as Hurricane Fiona. This peer support fostered a strong sense of belonging among the students, a crucial factor for student retention. About half of the students of all cohorts have continued taking advantage of research opportunities offered by PCUPR and outside universities. 

The RACE for Success in STEM project has not only improved students' academic outcomes but also provided a replicable model for integrating culturally responsive wraparound support into STEM education. The project’s success underscores the importance of addressing academic, social, and family contexts to foster equitable success in STEM fields.
